info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued January 09 at 12:24PM EST until January 09 at 7:15PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Madison County in western North Carolina... Mitchell County in western North Carolina... Yancey County in western North Carolina... * Until 715 PM EST Tuesday. * At 1224 PM EST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Significant rises are ongoing across Madison, Yancey, and Mitchell counties, including the South Toe River, North Toe River, Ivy River, and Cane River. Expect developing inundation of low-lying areas throughout the afternoon hours as it will take some time for high flows to move through area streams. Exercise caution while traveling. HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, farmland, greenways, parks, low-water crossings, campgrounds, streets, and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas. * Some locations that may experience flash flooding include... Spruce Pine, Burnsville, Marshall, Mars Hill, Hot Springs, Bakersville, Swiss, Wolf Ridge, Faust, Ramseytown, Poplar, Green Mountain, Micaville, Celo, Walnut, Bandana and Allenstand. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED
info.instruction: Heavy rain is increasing the risk of landslides, especially in areas where slides have occurred in the past. Be especially alert if you are near a stream, especially at the base of a mountain or in a cove. Watch for loose-moving soil and rocks or a sudden increase in streamflow. Leave the area quickly if this is observed. When driving along roads where the terrain is steep or rocky, watch and listen for falling rocks, mud, trees and other debris. Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads. In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route.
